passages.text: First Look: Solid 2Q; 2H Guidance Ahead of the Street

Friday morning, BRP reported 2Q26 adjusted EPS of \(\) 0.92\(, well ahead of our estimate of\) \ \(0.49\) and VA consensus of \(\) 0.46\(, although a lower tax rate added\) \ \(0.36\) vs. our number. Normalized EBITDA of \(\) 213M\$ was slightly ahead of our \(\) 209M\$ and the Street's \(\) 203M\$ , while \(10\%\) short of last year's \(\) 235M\$ . Management had spoken to a 2Q bottom line that would be similar to 1Q ( \(\) 201M\$ in EBITDA) and so this represents a modest beat on the EBITDA line vs. internal expectations. The 2Q beat vs. the Street stemmed from better shipments relative to retail that remains underwater, although the real news comes in the form of 2H guidance that is ahead of the Street on the top and bottom lines.

Total sales of \(\) 1.89B\$ were up \(4\%\) in the quarter, better than our flat estimate and the Street's estimate of \(- 2\%\) . North American Powersports retail for BRP's 2Q26 was down \(11\%\) , significantly worse than the flat retail in 1Q, although the biggest delta in this regard is the lack of contribution from snowmobiles (in the off- season as of 2Q; \(+80\%\) in 1Q). Side- by- side vehicles were down MSD (a bit better than \(- 10\%\) in 1Q), losing share vs. an industry that was \(+\) LSD, whereas ATVs were down LSDs along with the industry (both consistent with 1Q).

After refraining to provide guidance following both Q4 and Q1, BRP is providing FY26 guidance for the first time, with normalized EBITDA of \(\) 1.04- \(\) 1.09B\(vs. the Street's\) \ \(978M\) and our \(\) 997M\() and normalized EPS of\) \ \(4.25-\) \(\) 4.75\(vs. the Street's\) \ \(3.50\) and our \(\) 3.57\(. Net revenues are expected to be\) \ \(8.15 - \S 8.3B\) (vs. the Street's \(\) 7.91B\(and our\) \ \(7.93\) ) or an increase of \(3\%\) to \(5\%\) vs. last year's \(\) 7.9B\(. For 2H, revenues are implied to be up\) 8 - 12\% \(to\) \ \(4.4 - \S 4.6B\) (vs. the Street's \(\) 4.27B\(and our\) \ \(4.30B\) ), with Normalized EBITDA \(+22 - 31\%\) to \(\) 627- \(\) 676M\(vs. the Streets\) \ \(571M\) and our \(\) 579M\(), and Normalized EPS up \(28 - 51\%\) to \(\) 2.87- \(\) 3.37\(vs. the Street's\) \ \(2.56\) and our \(\) 2.62\$ .
BRP now expects \(\) 90M\(of tariffs this year compared to the previous estimate of\) \ \(60 - \S 70M\) .

Price (28 Aug 25 16:00) \(\) 79.00\(Target price\) \ \(69.00\) Expected share price return - 12.7% Expected dividend yield 1.1% Expected total return - 11.6% Market Cap \(\) 5,770M\(US\) \ \(4,196M\)
Price Performance (RIC: DOO.TO, BB: DOO CN)

Friday morning, BRP reported 2Q26 adjusted EPS of \(0.92,\) well ahead of our estimate of \(0.49\) and the consensus of \(0.46,\) although a lower tax rate added \(0.36\) vs. our number. Normalized EBITDA of \(\) 213M\(was slightly ahead of our\) \ \(209M\) and the Street's \(\) 203M\(, while\) 10\%\(short of last year's\) \ \(235M\) . Management had spoken to a 2Q bottom line that would be similar to 1Q ( \(\) 201M\(in EBITDA) and so this represents a modest beat on the EBITDA line vs. internal expectations. The 2Q beat vs. the Street stemmed from better shipments relative to retail that remains underwater, although the real news comes in the form of 2H guidance that is ahead of the Street on the top and bottom lines.

Total sales of \(\) 1.89B\(were up\) 4\%\(in the quarter, better than our flat estimate and the Street's estimate of\) - 2\%\(. Breaking down the Powersports revenue, Year - Round product revenue increased\) 13\%\((better than the Street's flat estimate and our - 5\%) whereas Seasonal product revenue decreased\) 13\%\((worse than the Street's - 6\%\) and our \(+10\%\) ). Powersports PA&A and OEM Engines were up \(7\%\) , better than the Street's - 4% and our - 1% estimate.

2Q gross margin was \(21.1\%\) , down 90 bps versus \(22.0\%\) last year, short of our estimate of \(22.1\%\) , but in line with the Street's \(21.2\%\) . Adjusted operating expenses came in at \(\) 296M\(, higher than the Street's\) \ \(278M\) but a bit better than our \(\) 300M\(, albeit up\) \ \(30M / 11\%\) Y/Y.

North American Powersports retail for BRP's 2Q26 was down \(11\%\) , significantly worse than the flat retail in 1Q, although the biggest delta in this regard is the lack of contribution from snowmobiles (in the off- season as of 2Q; \(+80\%\) in 1Q). Year- round products retail was down high- single digits (vs. down low- teens in 1Q and meaningfully worse than the low- single digit industry decline) as management called out elevated non- current inventory by its competitors and increased promotional intensity.

Side- by- side vehicles were down MSD (a bit better than - 10% in 1Q), losing share vs. an industry that was \(+LSD\) , whereas ATVs were down LSDs along with the industry (both consistent with 1Q). However, BRP noted share gains in current SSVs and ATVs (+MSD for the season vs. down low- teens for other OEMs), noting that Can- Am's leaner inventory levels resulted in lower availability of non- current units (down high- teens for BRP vs. up high- teens for other OEMs) and consequently in market share loss. Three- wheeled vehicles saw mid- 20's declines (better than high- 20's declines in 1Q) vs. an industry that was down low- 20's.

Seasonal products retail was down high teens (vs. the high- 20s 1Q growth and worse than the industry decrease in the mid- teens). BRP saw a mid- teen decline in personal watercrafts (worse than MSD decline in 1Q and the industry's low- teen decline in 2Q) and a mid- 20% decline in pontoons (wors than the 1Q low- 20% decline.

Network inventory was down \(20\%\) Y/Y, similar to the \(21\%\) Y/Y decline in 1Q. This consisted of ORV inventory - \(15\%\) (- 21% in Q1), 3WV - \(34\%\) (- 30% in Q1), PWC - \(31\%\) (- 19% in Q1), Switch - \(46\%\) (- 40% in Q1), and snowmobiles - \(10\%\) (- 15% in Q1).

After refraining to provide guidance following both Q4 and Q1, BRP is providing FY26 guidance for the first time, with normalized EBITDA of \(\) 1.04-\ \(1.09B\) (vs. the Street's \(\) 978M\(and our\) \ \(997M\) ) and normalized EPS of \(\) 4.25-\ \(4.75\) (vs. the Street's \(\) 3.50\(and our\) \ \(3.57\) ).

Net revenues are expected to be \(8.15 - 8.3B\) (vs. the Street's \(7.91B\) and our \(7.93B\) or an increase of \(3\%\) to \(5\%\) vs. last year's \(7.9B\) . Year- round product revenues are \(4.75 - 4.8B\) (vs. the Street's \(4.42B\) and our \(4.36B\) ) or an increase of \(10\%\) to \(11\%\) . Seasonal products revenues are guided \(2.15B - 2.20B\) (vs. the Street's \(2.27B\) and our \(2.30B\) ) or down \(7 - 9\%\) . Finally, PAA & A and OEM Engines revenues are guided \(1.25 - 1.3B\) (vs. the Street's \(1.23B\) and our \(1.27B\) ) or up \(2\%\) to \(6\%\) .

For 2H, revenues are implied to be up \(8 - 12\%\) to \(4.4 - 4.6B\) (vs. the Street's \(4.27B\) and our \(4.30B\) ), with Normalized EBITDA \(+22 - 31\%\) to \(627 - 676M\) (vs. the Streets \(571M\) and our \(579M\) ), and Normalized EPS up \(28 - 51\%\) to \(2.87 - 3.37\) (vs. the Street's \(2.56\) and our \(2.62\) ). BRP should benefit from wholesale being more aligned with retail following the right- sizing of network inventory, as well as initial shipments of newly- introduced models, notably the all- new Can- Am Defender. On the other side of the ledger, promotions will remain elevated, with tariff costs kicking in more meaningfully.
BRP now expects \(90M\) of tariffs this year compared to the previous estimate of \(60 - 70M\) .

BRP is a Canadian manufacturer of snowmobiles, off- road vehicles, motorcycles, and personal watercraft (and marine boats since 2018). BRP is a global leader in the design and manufacturing of powersports vehicles, which provides enthusiasts with a variety of exhilarating, stylish and powerful products for year- round use on a variety of terrains.

We rate BRP, Inc. shares a Neutral. While BRP is dealing with a deteriorating and increasingly promotional end market and the tariff landscape remains fluid, the company's supply chain setup manufacturing overwhelmingly in Mexico appears to have avoided the worst case, as tariffs on Mexico and Canada (at least for product that is USMCA compliant) appear to be on the backburner (at least for now), postponing if not eliminating a potentially existential threat. Meanwhile, BRP competes with companies that import a significant amount of product (relative to DOO) into the United States from China, a supply chain setup that has been disproportionately punished by tariffs.

Our target price of \(\) 69\(equates to a\) 15x P/E multiple on our FY27 estimate. On an EV/EBITDA basis, this equates to a \~6x multiple of our FY27 EBITDA estimate. This compares to historical multiples of \~15x P/E and \~8x EV/EBITDA.

Risks to our TP include: 1) Global Recession – the discretionary demand for outdoor recreation products would be negatively impacted; 2) Fixed Cost Model – operating leverage works both ways at any manufacturing business (margins fell more than revenue fell during the GFC); 3) International Trade Policy – BRP imports raw materials for production purposes and manufacturers the majority of its products outside of the United States exposing itself to tariffs; and 4) Dealer Network – dealers are independent operators and their financial health is essential for product distribution.
If the impact on the company from any of these factors proves to be more positive/negative than we anticipate, the stock will likely underperform/outperform our price target.

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks. Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

Investment Ratings: Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of \(15\%\) or more or \(25\%\) or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign "Rating Suspended" status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as "—" and "–" respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned "Under Review" status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re-establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short-term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management. Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk.

Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in reaction to one or more specific near- term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified 30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds \(15\%\) against the direction of the call (unless over- ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be different from and does not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer- term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings- distribution- disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution- disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in

our ratings distribution table for our Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share-price movement will not materialize as expected.
